LongTitle.Bpara: M ake provision about the functions of the Office of Communications; to make provision about the online infringement of copyright, about licensing of copyright and performers’ rights and about penalties for infringement; to make provision about internet domain registries; to make provision about the functions of the Channel Four Television Corporation; to make provision about the regulation of television and radio services; to make provision about the regulation of the use of the electromagnetic spectrum; to amend the Video Recordings Act 1984; to make provision about public lending right in relation to electronic publications; and for connected purposes.

WordsOfEnactment.Bpara: Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: General duties of OFCOM

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 3 of the Communications Act 2003 (general duties of OFCOM) is amended as follows.
After subsection (1) insert—
In performing their duties under subsection (1), OFCOM must have particular regard, in all cases, to the need—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to promote appropriate levels of investment in electronic communications networks;
to promote appropriate levels of investment in public service media content; and
for the investment to be efficient, wherever possible.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (2)(c) and (d), for “television and radio services” substitute “media services”.

In subsection (4)(m), for “the furthering or securing of the matters mentioned in subsections (1) and (2)” substitute “the furthering, promoting or securing of the matters mentioned in subsections (1), (1A) and (2)”.
In subsection (14), after the definition of “general duties” insert—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: ““media services” means any of the following services that are available to members of the public in all or part of the United Kingdom—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) television and radio services;
(b) on-demand programme services; and
(c) other services provided by means of the internet where there is a person who exercises editorial control over the material included in the service;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “public service media content” means material, other than advertisements, which is included in media services and which OFCOM consider contributes or may contribute towards the fulfilment of the public service objectives (as defined in section 264A);”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After that subsection insert—
The services that are to be taken for the purposes of this section to be available to members of the public include any service which—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: is available for reception by members of the public (within the meaning of section 361); or
is available for use by members of the public (within the meaning of section 368R(4)).”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: OFCOM reports on infrastructure, internet domain names etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Chapter 1 of Part 2 of the Communications Act 2003 (electronic communications networks and services), after section 134 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: OFCOM reports on infrastructure etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must prepare reports in accordance with subsections (2) and (3) on—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the electronic communications networks matters listed in section 134B(1), and
the electronic communications services matters listed in section 134B(2).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The first report must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: relate to the position on a day specified in the report which falls within the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which this section comes into force, and
be sent to the Secretary of State by OFCOM not more than 2 months after the specified day.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Each subsequent report must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: relate to a relevant period, and
be sent to the Secretary of State by OFCOM as soon as practicable after the end of the relevant period.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: “Relevant period” means—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the period of 2 years beginning with the day specified in the first report, and
each subsequent period of 2 years beginning with the end of the previous period.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where there is a significant change in connection with a matter listed in section 134B(1) or (2) and OFCOM consider that the change should be brought to the attention of the Secretary of State, OFCOM must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: prepare a report on the change, and
send it to the Secretary of State as soon as practicable.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of subsection (5), a change is significant if OFCOM consider that it has, or is likely to have, a significant adverse impact on—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: persons carrying on business in the United Kingdom or a part of the United Kingdom, or
the general public in the United Kingdom or a part of the United Kingdom.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Networks and services matters

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of section 134A, the electronic communications networks matters are—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the different types of electronic communications network provided in the United Kingdom (“UK networks”),
the geographic coverage of the different UK networks,
the proportion of the population covered by the different UK networks,
the extent to which UK networks share infrastructure,
the capacity of the different UK networks,
the extent to which the providers of the different UK networks allow other communications providers to use their networks to provide services,
the amount of time for which the different UK networks are and are not available, including the steps that have been or are to be taken to maintain or improve the level of availability,
the preparations made by providers of UK networks for responding to an emergency, including preparations for restoring normal operation of UK networks disrupted by the emergency, and
the standard of the different UK networks in comparison with electronic communications networks provided in a range of other countries, having regard, in particular, to their coverage and capacity.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of section 134A, the electronic communications services matters are—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the use of the electromagnetic spectrum for wireless telegraphy in the United Kingdom,
the different types of electronic communications service provided in the United Kingdom (“UK services”),
the geographic coverage of the different UK services,
the proportion of the population covered by the different UK services,
the amount of time for which the different UK services are and are not available, including the steps that have been or are to be taken to maintain or improve the level of availability,
the preparations made by providers of UK services for responding to an emergency, including preparations for restoring normal operation of UK services disrupted by the emergency, and
the standard of the different UK services in comparison with electronic communications services provided in a range of other countries.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The preparations referred to in subsections (1)(h) and (2)(f) include—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the steps taken to assess the risks of different types of emergency occurring,
the steps taken to reduce or remove those risks, and
the testing of proposed responses to different types of emergency.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In a report under section 134A, OFCOM are required to include only information about, and analysis of, such networks, services and providers as they consider appropriate.
In this section “emergency” means an event or situation that seriously disrupts a UK network or UK service.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: OFCOM reports on internet domain names

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must, if requested to do so by the Secretary of State—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: prepare a report on matters specified by the Secretary of State relating to internet domain names, and
send the report to the Secretary of State as soon as practicable.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The specified matters may, in particular, include matters relating to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the allocation and registration of internet domain names, and
the misuse of internet domain names.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 135(3) of that Act (information required for purposes of Chapter 1 functions), after paragraph (ib) insert—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: preparing a report under section 134A;
preparing a report under section 134C;”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: OFCOM reports on media content

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 264 of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: OFCOM reports: wider review and reporting obligations

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: When carrying out a review under section 264 for a period, OFCOM must also carry out a review of the extent to which material included in media services during that period (taken together over the period as a Page 5whole) contributed towards the fulfilment of the public service objectives.
Every report under section 264 must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: include a report on the matters found on the review under this section,
specify, and comment on, whatever changes appear to OFCOM to have occurred, during the period to which the report relates, in the extent to which the public service objectives have been fulfilled,
specify, and comment on, whatever changes appear to OFCOM to have occurred, during that period, in the manner in which those objectives are fulfilled, and
set out OFCOM’s conclusions on the current state of material included in media services.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: “The public service objectives” are the objectives set out in paragraphs (b) to (j) of section 264(6) (as modified by subsection (4)).
Paragraphs (b) to (j) of section 264(6) have effect for the purposes of subsection (3) as if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: references to the relevant television services were to media services, and
references to programmes were to material included in such services.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “material” does not include advertisements;
“media services” means any of the following services that are available to members of the public in all or part of the United Kingdom—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) television and radio services,
(b) on-demand programme services, and
(c) other services provided by means of the internet where there is a person who exercises editorial control over the material included in the service.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The services that are to be taken for the purposes of this section to be available to members of the public include any service which—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: is available for reception by members of the public (within the meaning of section 361); or
is available for use by members of the public (within the meaning of section 368R(4)).”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Obligation to notify subscribers of reported infringements

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124 of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

CrossHeading.CrossHeadingTitle: “Online infringement of copyright: obligations of internet service providers

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Obligation to notify subscribers of copyright infringement reports

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if it appears to a copyright owner that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a subscriber to an internet access service has infringed the owner’s copyright by means of the service; or
a subscriber to an internet access service has allowed another person to use the service, and that other person has infringed the owner’s copyright by means of the service.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The owner may make a copyright infringement report to the internet service provider who provided the internet access service if a code in force under section 124C or 124D (an “initial obligations code”) allows the owner to do so.
A “copyright infringement report” is a report that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: states that there appears to have been an infringement of the owner’s copyright;
includes a description of the apparent infringement;
includes evidence of the apparent infringement that shows the subscriber’s IP address and the time at which the evidence was gathered; and
complies with any other requirement of the initial obligations code.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An internet service provider who receives a copyright infringement report must notify the subscriber of the report if the initial obligations code requires the provider to do so.
A notification under subsection (4) must include—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a statement that it is sent under this section in response to a copyright infringement report made by a copyright owner;
a description of the apparent infringement;
evidence of the apparent infringement;
information about copyright and its purpose;
advice about how to obtain lawful access to copyright works;
advice about the protection of electronic communications networks that use wireless telegraphy; and
anything else that the initial obligations code requires it to include.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The things that may be required under subsection (5)(g), whether in general or in a particular case, include in particular statements that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: information about the apparent infringement may be kept by the internet service provider;
the copyright owner may require the provider to disclose which copyright infringement reports made by the owner to the provider relate to the subscriber;
following such a disclosure, the copyright owner may apply to a court to learn the subscriber’s identity and may bring proceedings against the subscriber for copyright infringement;
the number and nature of copyright infringement reports relating to the subscriber may be taken into account for the purposes of any technical measures.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section “notify”, in relation to a subscriber, means send a notification to the electronic or postal address held by the internet service provider for the subscriber (and sections 394 to 396 do not apply).”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Obligation to provide infringement lists to copyright owners

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124A of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Obligation to provide copyright infringement lists to copyright owners

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An internet service provider must provide a copyright owner with a copyright infringement list for a period if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the owner requests the list for that period; and
an initial obligations code requires the internet service provider to provide it.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A “copyright infringement list” is a list that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: sets out, in relation to each relevant subscriber, which of the copyright infringement reports made by the owner to the provider relate to the subscriber, but
does not enable any subscriber to be identified.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A subscriber is a “relevant subscriber” in relation to a copyright owner if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the owner has made one or more copyright infringement reports in relation to the subscriber; and
the number of the reports has reached the threshold (if any) set in the initial obligations code.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Approval of code about the initial obligations

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124B of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Approval of code about the initial obligations

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The obligations of internet service providers under sections 124A and 124B are the “initial obligations”.
If it appears to OFCOM—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that a code has been made by any person for the purpose of regulating the initial obligations; and
that it would be appropriate for them to approve the code for that purpose,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: they may approve it, with effect from the date given in the approval.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The provision that may be contained in a code and approved under this section includes provision that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: specifies conditions that must be met for rights and obligations under the copyright infringement provisions or the code to apply in a particular case;
requires copyright owners or internet service providers to provide any information or assistance that is reasonably required to determine whether a condition under paragraph (a) is met.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The provision mentioned in subsection (3)(a) may, in particular, specify that a right or obligation does not apply in relation to a copyright owner unless the owner has made arrangements with an internet service provider regarding—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the number of copyright infringement reports that the owner may make to the provider within a particular period; and
payment in advance of a contribution towards meeting costs incurred by the provider.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The provision mentioned in subsection (3)(a) may also, in particular, provide that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: except as provided by the code, rights and obligations do not apply in relation to an internet service provider unless the number of copyright infringement reports the provider receives within a particular period reaches a threshold set out in the code;
once the threshold is reached, rights or obligations apply in relation to a time before it was reached.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must not approve a code under this section unless satisfied that it meets the criteria set out in section 124E.
Not more than one approved code may have effect at a time.
OFCOM must keep an approved code under review.
OFCOM may, at any time, for the purpose mentioned in subsection (2)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: approve modifications that have been made to an approved code; or
withdraw their approval from an approved code,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: with effect from a date given in the approval or withdrawal, and must do so if the code ceases to meet the criteria set out in section 124E.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The consent of the Secretary of State is required for the approval of a code or the modification of an approved code.
Where OFCOM give or withdraw an approval under this section, they must give notification of their approval or of its withdrawal.

The notification must be published in such manner as OFCOM consider appropriate for bringing it to the attention of the persons who, in OFCOM’s opinion, are likely to be affected by the approval or withdrawal.
The notification and, where the notification is of an approval, the approved code or modifications to which it relates, must be laid by OFCOM before each House of Parliament.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Initial obligations code by OFCOM in the absence of an approved code

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124C of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Initial obligations code by OFCOM in the absence of an approved code

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For any period when sections 124A and 124B are in force but for which there is no approved initial obligations code under section 124C, OFCOM must by order make a code for the purpose of regulating the initial obligations.
OFCOM may, but need not, comply with subsection (1) so far as the period falls six months or less after sections 124A and 124B come into force.
A code under this section may do any of the things mentioned in section 124C(3) to (5).
A code under this section may also—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: establish one or more bodies corporate with the capacity to make their own rules and establish their own procedures;
determine the jurisdiction of a body established by the code or, for the purposes of the code, of any other person;
confer jurisdiction with respect to any matter on OFCOM themselves (but this is subject to anything else in or under the copyright infringement provisions that relates to appeals by subscribers);
provide for a person on whom jurisdiction is conferred to make awards of compensation, to direct the reimbursement of costs, or to do both;
provide for such a person to enforce, or to participate in the enforcement of, any awards or directions made under the code;
make other provision for the enforcement of such awards and directions; and
make other provision for the purpose of regulating the initial obligations.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must not make a code under this section unless they are satisfied that it meets the criteria set out in section 124E.
OFCOM must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: keep a code under this section under review; and
by order make any amendment of it that is necessary to ensure that while it is in force it continues to meet the criteria set out in section 124E.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The consent of the Secretary of State is required for the making or amendment by OFCOM of a code under this section.
Section 403 applies to the power of OFCOM to make an order under this section.
A statutory instrument containing an order made by OFCOM under this section is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Contents of initial obligations code

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124D of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Contents of initial obligations code

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The criteria referred to in sections 124C(6) and 124D(5) are—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that the code makes the required provision about copyright infringement reports (see subsection (2));
that it makes the required provision about the notification of subscribers (see subsection (3));
that it makes provision about how internet service providers are to keep information about subscribers;
that it limits the time for which they may keep that information;
that it makes any provision about contributions towards meeting costs that is required to be included by an order under section 124L;
that the requirements concerning enforcement and related matters are met in relation to the code (see subsection (4));
that the provisions of the code are objectively justifiable in relation to the matters to which it relates;
that those provisions are not such as to discriminate unduly against particular persons or against a particular description of persons;
that those provisions are proportionate to what they are intended to achieve; and
that, in relation to what those provisions are intended to achieve, they are transparent.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The required provision about copyright infringement reports is provision that specifies—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: requirements as to the means of obtaining evidence of infringement of copyright for inclusion in a report;
the standard of evidence that must be included;
the required form of the report; and
a time limit for making the report.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The required provision about the notification of subscribers is provision that specifies, in relation to a subscriber in relation to whom an internet service provider receives one or more copyright infringement reports—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: requirements as to the means by which the provider identifies the subscriber;
which of the reports the provider must notify the subscriber of; and
requirements as to the form, contents and means of the notification in each case.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The requirements concerning enforcement and related matters are—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that OFCOM or another person has, under the code, the functions of administering and enforcing it, including the function of resolving copyright infringement disputes;
that any such other person is sufficiently independent of internet service providers and copyright owners;
that there is a person who, under the code, has the function of determining subscriber appeals;
that that person is sufficiently independent of internet service providers, copyright owners and OFCOM; and

that there are adequate arrangements under the code for the costs of the carrying out by a person mentioned in paragraph (a) or (c) of functions in relation to the code to be met by internet service providers and copyright owners.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The provision mentioned in subsection (4) may include, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provision for the payment, to a person specified in the code, of a penalty not exceeding the maximum penalty for the time being specified in section 124K(2);

provision requiring a copyright owner to indemnify an internet service provider for any loss or damage resulting from the owner’s failure to comply with the code or the copyright infringement provisions.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “copyright infringement dispute” means a dispute that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) is between one or more copyright owners, internet service providers or subscribers; and
(b) relates to an act or omission in relation to an initial obligation or the initial obligations code;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “subscriber appeal” means an appeal by a subscriber about—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) a copyright infringement report;
(b) identification of the subscriber as a person in relation to whom the report was made;
(c) retention by an internet service provider of details of an alleged infringement; or
(d) inclusion of those details in a copyright infringement list.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Progress reports

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124E of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Progress reports

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must prepare the following reports for the Secretary of State about the infringement of copyright by subscribers to internet access services.
OFCOM must prepare a full report for—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the period of 12 months beginning with the first day on which there is an initial obligations code in force; and
each successive period of 12 months.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must prepare an interim report for—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the period of 3 months beginning with the first day on which there is an initial obligations code in force; and
each successive period of 3 months, other than one ending at the same time as a period of 12 months under subsection (2).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A full report under this section must include—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: an assessment of the current level of subscribers’ use of internet access services to infringe copyright;
a description of the steps taken by copyright owners to enable subscribers to obtain lawful access to copyright works;
a description of the steps taken by copyright owners to inform, and change the attitude of, members of the public in relation to the infringement of copyright;
an assessment of the extent of the steps mentioned in paragraphs (b) and (c);
an assessment of the extent to which copyright owners have made copyright infringement reports;
an assessment of the extent to which they have brought legal proceedings against subscribers in relation to whom such reports have been made;
an assessment of the extent to which any such proceedings have been against subscribers in relation to whom a substantial number of reports have been made; and
anything else that the Secretary of State directs OFCOM to include in the report.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An interim report under this section must include—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the assessments mentioned in subsection (4)(a), (e) and (f); and
anything else that the Secretary of State directs OFCOM to include in the report.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must send a report prepared under this section to the Secretary of State as soon as practicable after the end of the period for which it is prepared.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Obligations to limit internet access: assessment and preparation

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124F of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Obligations to limit internet access: assessment and preparation

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may direct OFCOM to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: assess whether one or more technical obligations should be imposed on internet service providers;
take steps to prepare for the obligations;
provide a report on the assessment or steps to the Secretary of State.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A “technical obligation”, in relation to an internet service provider, is an obligation for the provider to take a technical measure against particular subscribers to its service.
A “technical measure” is a measure that—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: limits the speed or other capacity of the service provided to a subscriber;
prevents a subscriber from using the service to gain access to particular material, or limits such use;
suspends the service provided to a subscriber; or
limits the service provided to a subscriber in another way.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The assessment and steps that the Secretary of State may direct OFCOM to carry out or take under subsection (1) include, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: consultation of copyright owners, internet service providers, subscribers or any other person;
an assessment of the likely efficacy of a technical measure in relation to a particular type of internet access service; and
steps to prepare a proposed technical obligations code.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Internet service providers must give OFCOM any assistance that OFCOM reasonably require for the purposes of complying with any direction under this section.
The Secretary of State must lay before Parliament any direction under this section.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Obligations to limit internet access

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124G of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Obligations to limit internet access

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may at any time by order impose a technical obligation on internet service providers if the Secretary of State considers it appropriate in view of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: an assessment carried out or steps taken by OFCOM under section 124G; or
any other consideration.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under this section must specify the date from which the technical obligation is to have effect, or provide for it to be specified.
The order may also specify—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the criteria for taking the technical measure concerned against a subscriber;
the steps to be taken as part of the measure and when they are to be taken.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Code by OFCOM about obligations to limit internet access

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124H of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Code by OFCOM about obligations to limit internet access

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For any period during which there are one or more technical obligations in force under section 124H, OFCOM must by order make a technical obligations code for the purpose of regulating those obligations.
The code may be made separately from, or in combination with, any initial obligations code made under section 124D.
A code under this section may—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: do any of the things mentioned in section 124C(3) to (5) or section 124D(4)(a)to (f)); and
make other provision for the purpose of regulating the technical obligations.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must not make a code under this section unless they are satisfied that it meets the criteria set out in section 124J.
OFCOM must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: keep a code under this section under review; and
by order make any amendment of it that is necessary to ensure that while it is in force it continues to meet the criteria set out in section 124J.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The consent of the Secretary of State is required for the making or amendment by OFCOM of a code under this section.
Section 403 applies to the power of OFCOM to make an order under this section.
A statutory instrument containing an order made by OFCOM under this section is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Contents of code about obligations to limit internet access

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124I of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Contents of code about obligations to limit internet access

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The criteria referred to in section 124I(4) are—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that the requirements concerning enforcement and related matters are met in relation to the code (see subsection (2));
that it makes any provision about contributions towards meeting costs that is required to be included by an order under section 124L;
that it makes any other provision that the Secretary of State requires it to make;
that the provisions of the code are objectively justifiable in relation to the matters to which it relates;
that those provisions are not such as to discriminate unduly against particular persons or against a particular description of persons;
that those provisions are proportionate to what they are intended to achieve; and
that, in relation to what those provisions are intended to achieve, they are transparent.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The requirements concerning enforcement and related matters are—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that OFCOM or another person has, under the code, the functions of administering and enforcing it, including the function of resolving copyright infringement disputes;
that any such other person is sufficiently independent of internet service providers and copyright owners;
that there is a person who, under the code, has the function of determining subscriber appeals;
that that person is sufficiently independent of internet service providers, copyright owners and OFCOM;

that there are adequate arrangements under the code for the costs of the carrying out by a person mentioned in paragraph (a) or (c) of functions in relation to the code to be met by internet service providers and copyright owners; and
that provision is made, in accordance with subsection (3), for the appeal to the First-tier Tribunal of determinations of subscriber appeals.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The provision mentioned in subsection (2)(f) is provision—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: enabling a determination of a subscriber appeal to be appealed to the First-tier Tribunal, including on grounds that it was based on an error of fact, wrong in law or unreasonable;
giving the First-tier Tribunal power, in relation to an appeal to it, to—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: take any steps that a person administering or enforcing the code could take in relation to the act or omission giving rise to the technical measure;
remit the decision whether to confirm the technical measure, or any matter relating to that decision, to a person mentioned in subsection (2)(c);

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in relation to recovery of costs awarded by the Tribunal.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The provision mentioned in subsection (2) may also (unless the Secretary of State requires otherwise) include, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provision for the payment, to a person specified in the code, of a penalty not exceeding the maximum penalty for the time being specified in section 124K(2);

provision requiring a copyright owner to indemnify an internet service provider for any loss or damage resulting from the owner’s infringement or error in relation to the code or the copyright infringement provisions;
provision for the taking of a technical measure to be postponed until a subscriber appeal to a person mentioned in subsection (2)(c) or an appeal to the First-tier Tribunal has been determined.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “copyright infringement dispute” means a dispute that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) is between one or more copyright owners, internet service providers or subscribers; and
(b) relates to an act or omission in relation to a technical obligation or the technical obligations code;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “subscriber appeal” means an appeal by a subscriber against—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) the proposed taking of a technical measure against a subscriber; or
(b) the taking of a technical measure against a subscriber.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Enforcement of obligations

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124J of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Enforcement of obligations

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Sections 94 to 96 apply in relation to a contravention of an initial obligation or a technical obligation, or a contravention of an obligation under section 124G(5), as they apply in relation to a contravention of a condition set out under section 45.
The amount of the penalty imposed under section 96 as applied by this section is to be such amount not exceeding £250,000 as OFCOM determine to be—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: appropriate; and
proportionate to the contravention in respect of which it is imposed.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In making that determination OFCOM must have regard to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: any representations made to them by the internet service provider;
any steps taken by the provider towards complying with the obligations contraventions of which have been notified to the provider under section 94 (as applied); and
any steps taken by the provider for remedying the consequences of those contraventions.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by order amend this section so as to substitute a different maximum penalty for the maximum penalty for the time being specified in subsection (2).
No order is to be made containing provision authorised by subsection (4) unless a draft of the order has been laid before Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Sharing of costs

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124K of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Sharing of costs

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by order specify provision that must be included in an initial obligations code or a technical obligations code about payment of contributions towards costs incurred under the copyright infringement provisions.
Provision specified under subsection (1) may relate to, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: payment by a copyright owner of a contribution towards the costs that an internet service provider incurs;
payment by a copyright owner or internet service provider of a contribution towards the costs that OFCOM incur.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Provision specified under subsection (1) may include, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provision about costs incurred before the provision is included in an initial obligations code or a technical obligations code;
provision for payment in advance of expected costs (and for reimbursement of overpayments where the costs incurred are less than expected);
provision about how costs, expected costs or contributions must be calculated;
other provision about when and how contributions must be paid.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Interpretation and consequential provision

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 124L of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Interpretation

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: In sections 124A to 124L and this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “apparent infringement”, in relation to a copyright infringement report, means the infringement of copyright that the report states appears to have taken place;
“copyright infringement list” has the meaning given in section 124B(2);
“copyright infringement provisions” means sections 124A to 124L and this section;
“copyright infringement report” has the meaning given in section 124A(3);
“copyright owner” means—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) a copyright owner within the meaning of Part 1 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (see section 173 of that Act); or
(b) someone authorised by that person to act on the person’s behalf;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “copyright work” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (see section 1(2) of that Act);
“initial obligations” has the meaning given in section 124C(1);
“initial obligations code” has the meaning given in section 124A(2);
“internet access service” means an electronic communications service that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) is provided to a subscriber;
(b) consists entirely or mainly of the provision of access to the internet; and
(c) includes the allocation of an IP address or IP addresses to the subscriber to enable that access;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “internet service provider” means a person who provides an internet access service;
“IP address” means an internet protocol address;
“subscriber”, in relation to an internet access service, means a person who—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) receives the service under an agreement between the person and the provider of the service; and
(b) does not receive it as a communications provider;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “technical measure” has the meaning given in section 124G(3);
“technical obligation” has the meaning given in section 124G(2);
“technical obligations code” means a code for the time being in force under section 124I.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 135(3) of that Act (information required for purposes of Chapter 1 functions), after paragraph (i) insert—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: preparing a report under section 124F;
carrying out an assessment, taking steps or providing a report under section 124G;”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Schedule 8 to that Act (decisions not subject to appeal to the Competition Appeal Tribunal), after paragraph 9 insert—

Paragraph.sch_PgfTag.Para.sch_text: A decision relating to any of sections 124A to 124M or to anything done under them.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Power to amend copyright provisions

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: In Part 7 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (miscellaneous and general) after section 302 insert—

CrossHeading.CrossHeadingTitle: “Prevention or reduction of online infringement of copyright

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Power to amend Part 1 and this Part

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by order amend Part 1 or this Part for the purpose of preventing or reducing the infringement of copyright by means of the internet, if it appears to the Secretary of State appropriate to do so having regard to technological developments that have occurred or are likely to occur.
The following provisions apply to the power conferred by this section.
Subsections (4) to (6) do not limit that power.
The power may be exercised so as to make new provision or to amend or repeal provision (whenever made).
The power may be exercised so as to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: confer a power or right or impose a duty on any person;
modify or remove a power, right or duty of any person;
require a person to pay fees.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The power includes power to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: make different provision for different cases;
make transitional or saving provision;
make any consequential amendment, repeal or revocation of provision (whenever made) contained in or made under an Act.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The power does not include power to create or modify a criminal offence.
An order under this section must be made by statutory instrument.

Before making any order under this section the Secretary of State must consult such persons who the Secretary of State thinks likely to be Page 19affected by the order, or who represent any of those persons, as the Secretary of State thinks fit.
A statutory instrument containing an order under this section may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before and approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament.”

CrossHeading.CrossHeadingTitle: Powers in relation to internet domain registries

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Powers in relation to internet domain registries

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124M of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

CrossHeading.CrossHeadingTitle: “Powers in relation to internet domain registries

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Notification of failure in relation to internet domain registry

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where the Secretary of State—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: is satisfied that a serious relevant failure in relation to an internet domain registry is taking place or has taken place, and
wishes to exercise the powers under section 124O or 124Q.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State must notify the internet domain registry, specifying the failure and a period during which the registry has the opportunity to make representations to the Secretary of State.
There is a relevant failure in relation to an internet domain registry if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the registry, or any of its registrars or end-users, engages in prescribed practices that are unfair or involve the misuse of internet domain names, or
the arrangements made by the registry for dealing with complaints in connection with internet domain names do not comply with prescribed requirements.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A relevant failure is serious, for the purposes of this section, if it has adversely affected or is likely adversely to affect—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the reputation or availability of electronic communications networks or electronic communications services provided in the United Kingdom or a part of the United Kingdom, or
the interests of consumers or members of the public in the United Kingdom or a part of the United Kingdom.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section and sections 124O to 124Q—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “end-user”, in relation to an internet domain registry, means a person who has been or wants to be allocated an internet domain name that is or would be included in the register maintained by the registry;
“internet domain” means an internet domain indicated by the last element of an internet domain name or by that element together with one or more of the preceding elements of the name;
“internet domain registry” means a relevant body that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) maintains a register of all of the internet domain names that belong to a particular internet domain, and

(b) operates a computer program or server that forms part of the system that enables the names included in the register to be used to access internet portal addresses or other information by means of the internet;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “prescribed” means prescribed by regulations made by the Secretary of State;
“registrar”, in relation to an internet domain registry, means a person authorised by the registry to act on behalf of end-users in connection with the registration of internet domain names;
“relevant body” means a company formed and registered under the Companies Act 2006 or a limited liability partnership.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Appointment of manager of internet domain registry

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 124N of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Appointment of manager of internet domain registry

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the Secretary of State has given a notification under section 124N to an internet domain registry specifying a failure,
the period allowed for making representations has expired, and
the Secretary of State is satisfied that the registry has not taken the steps that the Secretary of State considers appropriate for remedying the failure and any consequences of the failure.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by order appoint a manager in respect of the property and affairs of the internet domain registry for the purpose of securing that the registry takes the steps described in subsection (1)(c).
The person appointed may be anyone whom the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.
The appointment of the manager does not affect—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a right of a person to appoint a receiver of the registry’s property, or
the rights of a receiver appointed by a person other than the Secretary of State.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: keep the order under review, and
if appropriate, discharge all or part of the order.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State must discharge the order on the appointment of a person to act as administrative receiver, administrator, provisional liquidator or liquidator of the registry.
When discharging an order under this section, the Secretary of State may make savings and transitional provision.
The Secretary of State must send a copy of an order made under this section to the registry as soon as practicable after it is made.
In subsection (4), “receiver” includes a manager (other than a manager appointed by the registry) and a person who is appointed as both receiver and manager.
In subsection (6)—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “administrative receiver” means an administrative receiver within the meaning of section 251 of the Insolvency Act 1986 or Article 5(1) of the Insolvency (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 (S.I. 1989/2405 (N.I. 19));
“administrator” means a person appointed to manage the affairs, business and property of the registry under Schedule B1 to that Act or Schedule B1 to that Order.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Functions of manager etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under section 124O may make provision about the functions to be exercised by, and the powers of, the manager.
The order may, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provide for the manager to have such of the functions of the registry’s directors as are specified in the order (including functions exercisable only by a particular director or class of directors), and
provide for the registry’s directors to be prevented from exercising any of those functions.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The order may make provision about the remuneration of the manager, including in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provision for the amount of the remuneration to be determined by the Secretary of State, and
provision for the remuneration to be payable from the property of the registry.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In carrying out the functions conferred by the order, the manager acts as the registry’s agent.

The Secretary of State may apply to the court for directions in relation to any matter arising in connection with the functions or powers of the manager (and the costs of the application are to be paid by the registry).
On an application under subsection (5) the court may give such directions or make such orders as it thinks fit.
In this section “the court” means—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in England and Wales, the High Court or a county court,
in Scotland, the Court of Session or the sheriff, and
in Northern Ireland, the High Court.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where the registry is a limited liability partnership, this section applies as if references to a director of the registry were references to a member of the limited liability partnership.”
In section 192(1)(d) of that Act (appeals against decisions of the Secretary of State), after sub-paragraph (ii) insert—
In section 402(1) of that Act (powers of the Secretary of State to make orders and regulations), after “conferred by” insert “section 124O and”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Application to court to alter constitution of internet domain registry

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 124P of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Application to court to alter constitution of internet domain registry

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the Secretary of State has given a notification under section 124N to an internet domain registry specifying a failure,
the period allowed for making representations has expired, and
the Secretary of State is satisfied that the registry has not taken the steps that the Secretary of State considers appropriate for remedying the failure and any consequences of the failure.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may apply to the court (as defined in section 124P) for an order under this section.
The court may make an order—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: making alterations of the registry’s constitution, and
requiring the registry not to make any alterations, or any specified alterations, of its constitution without the leave of the court.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under this section may contain only such provision as the court considers appropriate for securing that the registry remedies the failure specified in the notification under section 124N and any consequences of the failure.
In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “constitution” means, in the case of a company, the articles of association and, in the case of a limited liability partnership, the limited liability partnership agreement;

“limited liability partnership agreement” means the agreement or agreements, whether express or implied, between the members of a limited liability partnership, and between the partnership and the members of the partnership, determining—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) the mutual rights and duties of the members, and
(b) their rights and duties in relation to the partnership.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Functions of C4C in relation to media content

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Before section 199 of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: C4C’s functions in relation to media content

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: C4C must participate in—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the making of a broad range of relevant media content of high quality that, taken as a whole, appeals to the tastes and interests of a culturally diverse society,
the making of high quality films intended to be shown to the general public at the cinema in the United Kingdom, and
the broadcasting and distribution of such content and films.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: C4C must, in particular, participate in—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the making of relevant media content that consists of news and current affairs,
the making of relevant media content that appeals to the tastes and interests of older children and young adults,
the broadcasting or distribution by means of electronic communications networks of feature films that reflect cultural activity in the United Kingdom (including third party films), and
the broadcasting or distribution of relevant media content by means of a range of different types of electronic communications networks.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In performing their duties under subsections (1) and (2) C4C must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: promote measures intended to secure that people are well-informed and motivated to participate in society in a variety of ways, and
contribute towards the fulfilment of the public service objectives (as defined in section 264A).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In performing their duties under subsections (1) to (3) C4C must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: support the development of people with creative talent, in particular—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: people at the beginning of their careers in relevant media content or films, and
people involved in the making of innovative content and films,

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: support and stimulate well-informed debate on a wide range of issues, in particular by challenging established views,
promote alternative views and new perspectives, and
provide access to material that is intended to inspire people to make changes in their lives.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In performing those duties C4C must have regard to the desirability of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: working with cultural organisations,
encouraging innovation in the means by which relevant media content is broadcast or distributed, and
promoting access to and awareness of services provided in digital form.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “participate in” includes invest in or otherwise procure;

“relevant media content” means material, other than advertisements, which is included in any of the following services that are available to members of the public in all or part of the United Kingdom—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) television programme services, additional television services or digital additional television services,
(b) on-demand programme services, or
(c) other services provided by means of the internet where there is a person who exercises editorial control over the material included in the service;

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: and a film is a “third party film” if C4C did not participate in making it.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The services that are to be taken for the purposes of this section to be available to members of the public include any service which—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: is available for reception by members of the public (within the meaning of section 361); or
is available for use by members of the public (within the meaning of section 368R(4)).”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 199(2) of that Act (functions of C4C), for “C4C’s primary functions are” substitute “In subsection (1) “primary functions” means—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the performance of C4C’s duties under section 198A;”

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: and in the heading for that section, at the beginning insert “Other”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Schedule 9 to that Act (arrangements about carrying on C4C’s activities)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in paragraph 1(1), after paragraph (a) (but before “and”) insert—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: as soon as practicable after the day on which section 198A comes into force,”,

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in paragraph 10, in the definition of “relevant licence period”, after paragraph (a) (but before “and”) insert—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: “(aa) in relation to the notification under paragraph 1(1)(aa), the period beginning on the day on which section 198A comes into force and ending on the last day of the first licence period to expire after that day;”, and

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in that definition, in paragraph (b), for “any other such notification” substitute “any other notification under paragraph 1”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Accordingly, in the heading for Part 3 of that Act (television and radio services), at the end insert “ETC”.
In section 24(1) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (Channel 4 to be provided by C4C), for “The function of the Corporation shall be to” substitute “The Corporation must”.
In paragraph 1 of Schedule 3 to that Act (status and capacity of C4C)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in sub-paragraph (4)(b), for “primary functions” substitute “Channel 4 functions”, and
after that sub-paragraph insert—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: securing the continued provision of Channel 4, and
the fulfilment of the public service remit for that Channel under section 265 of the Communications Act 2003.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Monitoring and enforcing C4C’s media content duties

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 198A of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Statement of media content policy

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: C4C must prepare a statement of media content policy—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: at the same time as they prepare the first statement of programme policy that is prepared under section 266 after this section comes into force, and
subsequently at annual intervals.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: C4C must monitor their performance in carrying out the proposals contained in their statements of media content policy.
A statement of media content policy must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: set out C4C’s proposals for securing that, during the following year, they will discharge their duties under section 198A, and
include a report on their performance in carrying out the proposals contained in the previous statement.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In preparing the statement, C4C must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: have regard to guidance given by OFCOM, and
consult OFCOM.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: C4C must publish each statement of media content policy—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: as soon as practicable after its preparation is complete, and
in such manner as they consider appropriate, having regard to any guidance given by OFCOM.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: from time to time review the guidance for the time being in force for the purposes of this section, and
revise that guidance as they think fit.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: OFCOM reports on C4C’s media content duties

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For each relevant period, OFCOM must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: carry out a review of the extent to which C4C have discharged their duties under section 198A, and
prepare a report on the matters found on the review.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must publish each report under this section—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: as soon as practicable after its preparation is complete, and
in such manner as they consider appropriate.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: “Relevant period” means each period selected by OFCOM for the purposes of section 264(1)(b) that ends after this section comes into force.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Directions in relation to C4C’s media content duties

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if OFCOM—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: are of the opinion that C4C have failed to perform one or more of their duties under section 198A or section 198B(1), (3) or (5),
are of the opinion that the failure is serious and is not excused by economic or market conditions, and
determine that the situation requires the exercise of their functions under this section.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In making a determination under subsection (1)(c), OFCOM must have regard, in particular, to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: C4C’s statements of media content policy,
C4C’s effectiveness and efficiency in monitoring their own performance, and
general economic and market conditions affecting the provision of relevant media content (as defined in section 198A).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may give directions to C4C to do one or both of the following—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to revise the latest statement of media content policy in accordance with the direction;
to take such steps for remedying the failure as OFCOM specify in the direction.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A direction given under this section must set out—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a reasonable timetable for complying with it, and
the factors that OFCOM will take into account in determining whether or not a failure has been remedied.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must consult C4C before giving a direction under this section.”
After section 271 of that Act insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Remedying failure by C4C to perform media content duties

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if OFCOM are satisfied—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that C4C have failed to comply with a direction under section 198D in respect of a failure to perform one or more of their duties under section 198A,
that C4C are still failing to perform that duty or those duties, and
that it would be both reasonable and proportionate to the seriousness of the failure to vary the licence under which Channel 4 is licensed (“the Channel 4 licence”) in accordance with this section.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may, by notice to C4C, vary the Channel 4 licence by adding such conditions, or making such modifications of conditions, as OFCOM consider appropriate for remedying (entirely or partly) C4C’s failure to perform the duty or duties under section 198A.

If, at any time following such a variation, OFCOM consider that any of the additional conditions or modifications is no longer necessary, they may again vary the licence with effect from such time as they may determine.
OFCOM must consult C4C before exercising their power under this section to vary the Channel 4 licence.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Determination of Channel 3 licence areas

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 14 of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (establishment of Channel 3)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: omit subsection (7) (restriction on providing a single Channel 3 service for the whole of England or the whole of Scotland), and
after that subsection insert—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The areas mentioned in subsection (2) must at all times include at least one area that comprises, or falls entirely within, Scotland.”
Section 216 of the Communications Act 2003 (renewal of Channel 3 and 5 licences) is amended as follows.
For subsection (4) substitute—
Where OFCOM receive an application under this section for the renewal of a licence they must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: decide whether to renew the licence; and
notify the applicant of their decision.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: If OFCOM decide to renew the licence they must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in the case of a licence to provide a Channel 3 service, determine in accordance with section 216A the area for which the licence will be renewed;
in every case, determine in accordance with section 217 the financial terms on which the licence will be renewed; and
notify the applicant of their determinations.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After subsection (6) insert—

OFCOM may also decide not to renew a licence to provide a Channel 3 service if, for the licensing period in question, they have renewed or propose to renew one or more other licences to provide a Channel 3 service for all of the area to which the licence relates.”
In subsection (8)(a) for “subsection (4)(c)” substitute “subsection (4A)(c)”.
In subsection (10) for the words from “, in accordance” to the end substitute “—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to any determination under subsection (4A)(a);

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 216 of that Act insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Renewal of Channel 3 licences: determination of licence areas

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if OFCOM decide under section 216(4) to renew a licence to provide a Channel 3 service.
The area determined under section 216(4A)(a) for the licence—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: must include all or part of the area to which the licence being renewed currently relates, and
may include all or part of another area if the holder of the licence to provide a Channel 3 service for the other area gives (and does not withdraw) consent before the determination is made.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 217(1) of that Act, in the opening words, for “section 216(4)(b)” substitute “section 216(4A)(b)”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Initial expiry date for Channel 3 and 5 and public teletext licences

Subject to any postponement under this section, for the purposes of this Part the initial expiry date for the following types of licence is 31 December 2014—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a licence to provide a Channel 3 service;
a licence to provide Channel 5;
the licence to provide the public teletext service.”

Omit subsection (3) (no postponement if digital switchover is to occur before 1 July 2013).

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Initial expiry date: consequential provision

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In each of sections 219(3) and 222(12) (definition of “licensing period” for public teletext service)—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 225(3) (period for review of financial terms of replacement Channel 3 and 5 and public teletext licences), after “initial expiry date” insert “for that type of licence”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 229 (report in anticipation of new licensing round) is amended as follows.

In subsection (2)—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (3)(a) and (b), for “relevant licences” substitute “that type of licence”.
After subsection (4) insert—
Subsection (5) applies where the Secretary of State—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: receives a report under this section in anticipation of the end of a licensing period for a type of relevant licence, and
subsequently makes an order under section 224 extending the licensing period for that type of licence.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (6), in the definition of “licensing period”—
