ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Report by OFCOM on public teletext service

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 218 of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Duty to report on public teletext service

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: prepare a report on the public teletext service, and
send it to the Secretary of State as soon as practicable after this section comes into force.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must prepare and send to the Secretary of State further reports on the public teletext service when asked to do so by the Secretary of State.
Each report must include, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: an assessment of the advantages and disadvantages for members of the public of the public teletext service being provided, and
an assessment of whether the public teletext service can be provided at a cost to the licence holder that is commercially sustainable.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An assessment under subsection (3)(a) must take account of alternative uses for the capacity that would be available if the public teletext service were not provided.
“Capacity” means capacity on the frequencies on which Channel 3 services, Channel 4, S4C and television multiplex services are broadcast.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Power to remove OFCOM’s duty to secure provision of public teletext service

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 218 of the Communications Act 2003 (provision of public teletext service) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for “must do all that they can to” substitute “may”, and
at the end insert “and complies with this section”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (7)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for “OFCOM must exercise their powers” substitute “If there is a public teletext provider, OFCOM must take account of the requirements of the public teletext service when exercising their powers”, and
omit the words after paragraph (b).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Accordingly, in the heading of the section, for “Duty” substitute “Power”.
Omit section 221 of that Act (replacement of existing public teletext provider’s licence).

In section 276(1) of that Act (co-operation with the public teletext provider), for “the provider of the service or channel” substitute “, if there is a public teletext provider, the provider of the Channel 3 service or Channel 4”.
In section 362 of that Act (interpretation of Part 3), in the definition of “the public teletext service”, for “is required to be” substitute “is or may be”.

The amendments made by this section and the entries in Schedule 3 relating to sections 218(7) and 221 of the Communications Act 2003 (and section 46 so far as relating to those entries) come into force on such day as the Secretary of State may by order made by statutory instrument appoint.
An order may not be made under subsection (8) unless—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: condition A or B is met,
the Secretary of State is satisfied that making the order is in the public interest, and
a draft of the instrument containing the order has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Condition A is that the Secretary of State has laid before Parliament a report by the Office of Communications (“OFCOM”) under section 218A of the Communications Act 2003 (report on public teletext service).
Condition B is that OFCOM have invited applications for the licence to provide the public teletext service (within the meaning of Part 3 of the Communications Act 2003) and—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: no applications were made by the closing date, or
OFCOM considered that they could not award the licence to any of the applicants.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Appointed providers of regional or local news

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 287 of the Communications Act 2003 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Appointed providers of regional or local news

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: appoint a person to provide relevant media content consisting of regional news or local news (or both) for all or part of a designated Channel 3 area, and
pay amounts to the appointed person for use in, or in connection with, the provision of such content.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where a person has been appointed under this section to provide news for all or part of a designated Channel 3 area, the regulatory regime for the regional Channel 3 service provided for that area includes the conditions (if any) that OFCOM consider appropriate for securing that the service includes news programmes provided by that person.
OFCOM must publish the criteria that they intend to use in making an appointment under this section.
The appointment—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: must specify the period for which the person is appointed,
must specify the area for which the person is appointed (the “appointed area”),
may specify the parts of the appointed area, or the communities, for which the appointed person is to provide local news,
may make provision for the variation of the appointment, including the appointed area,
may be made subject to such conditions as OFCOM consider appropriate, and
may be revoked by OFCOM at any time.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The conditions may include, in particular, conditions requiring the appointed person to make the relevant media content available to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the provider of the regional Channel 3 service for the appointed area,
the body corporate appointed under section 280 as the appointed news provider for Channel 3, and
any other person.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The conditions may also include, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: conditions relating to the form, character and quality of the relevant media content,
conditions requiring the appointed person to broadcast or distribute the relevant media content, whether by means Page 32involving the use of an electronic communications network or otherwise, and

conditions requiring the appointed person to support and promote the provision by other persons of regional news or local news (or both) for the appointed area, whether in the form of relevant media content or otherwise.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An amount paid under this section may be paid on such conditions as OFCOM consider appropriate, including—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: conditions as to the use of the amount, and
conditions as to the circumstances in which all or part of the amount must be repaid.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 287(5) and (6) apply to a condition imposed under subsection (2) as they apply to a condition imposed under that section.
OFCOM must consult the Secretary of State—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: before publishing criteria in accordance with subsection (3), and
before determining conditions to be imposed under subsection (4)(e) or (7).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “designated Channel 3 area” means an area—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) for which a regional Channel 3 service is provided, and
(b) which has been designated for the purposes of this section by OFCOM with the consent of the Secretary of State;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “local news”, for an appointed area, means news that is intended to be of particular interest to persons living within a part of the area or to a particular community living within the area;
“regional news”, for an appointed area, means news that is intended to be of particular interest to persons living within the area;

“relevant media content” means material, other than advertisements, which is included, or is capable of being included, in any of the following services that are available to members of the public in all or part of the United Kingdom—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) television programme services, additional television services or digital additional television services,
(b) on-demand programme services, or
(c) other services provided by means of the internet where there is a person who exercises editorial control over the material included in the service.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The services that are to be taken for the purposes of this section to be available to members of the public include any service which—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: is available for reception by members of the public (within the meaning of section 361); or
is available for use by members of the public (within the meaning of section 368R(4)).”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Broadcasting of programmes in Gaelic

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Omit section 184 of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (broadcasting of programmes in Gaelic on Channel 3 in Scotland).
Accordingly, omit section 183A(7)(a) and (b) of that Act (representation in Gaelic Media Service of interests of holders of certain licences).

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Digital switchover

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 86(6) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (varying licences under Part 3), for “section 110(1)(b)” substitute “section 97B or 110(1)(b)”.
After section 97 of that Act insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Date for digital switchover

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may give notice to OFCOM nominating a date for digital switchover for the post-commencement services specified or described in the notice.

When nominating a date, or considering whether to nominate a date, the Secretary of State must have regard to any report submitted by OFCOM or the BBC under section 67(1)(b) of the Broadcasting Act 1996 (review of digital radio broadcasting).
The Secretary of State—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: may nominate different dates for different services, and
may give notice to OFCOM withdrawing a nomination under this section.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section and section 97B—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “date for digital switchover”, in relation to a post-commencement service, means a date after which it will cease to be appropriate for the service to continue to be provided in analogue form;
“post-commencement service” means a local service, national service or additional service that is provided under a licence that—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) was granted on or after the day on which this section comes into force, or
(b) has been renewed under section 103B or 104AA.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Variation of licence period after date for digital switchover nominated

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if the Secretary of State has nominated a date for digital switchover for a post-commencement service (and has not withdrawn the nomination).

If the period for which the licence to provide the post-commencement service is to continue in force ends after the date for digital switchover, OFCOM must by notice vary the licence so that the period ends on or before that date, subject to subsection (3).
OFCOM may not reduce the period so that it ends less than 2 years after the day on which they issue the notice, unless the licence holder consents to such a reduction.

If the period for which the licence to provide the post-commencement service is to continue in force ends on or before the date for digital switchover, OFCOM may not vary the licence so that the period ends after that date.”
In section 199(5) of that Act (publication of notices by OFCOM), after “55,” insert “97B,”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Renewal of national radio licences

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 103A of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (renewal of national licences), in subsection (1), after “renewed” insert “under this section”.
After that section insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Further renewal of national licences

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A national licence may be renewed under this section on one occasion for a period of not more than 7 years beginning with the date of renewal (“the renewal period”) (subject to the following provisions of this section).

Subsections (2) to (9), (11) and (12) of section 103A apply in relation to the renewal of a licence under this section as they apply in relation to the renewal of a licence under section 103A, subject to subsection (3).
Those provisions apply in relation to the renewal of a licence under this section as if the following were omitted—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: subsection (4)(b),
in subsection (4)(c), the words from “or OFCOM” to the end,
subsection (6)(a),
subsection (8)(a), and
subsection (9)(c).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where OFCOM renew a licence under this section they must include in the licence as renewed a condition requiring the licence holder to do all that the licence holder can to secure the broadcasting of a simulcast radio service in digital form throughout the renewal period.”

Section 103A(12) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (as applied by section 103B of that Act) does not prevent the determination of a date falling less than one year after the making of the determination where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the Office of Communications consider that the relevant date for the purposes of that section (as applied) is a date which is not more than 15 months after the day on which this section comes into force, and
the determination is made as soon as practicable after that day.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Renewal and variation of local radio licences

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 104A of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (renewal of local licences)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in subsection (1), after “renewed” insert “under this section”, and
after that subsection insert—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A local licence may be renewed under this section only if it is granted before the day on which section 104AA comes into force.”
After that section insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Further renewal of local licences

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A local licence may be renewed under this section on one occasion for a period of not more than 7 years beginning with the date of renewal (subject to the following provisions of this section and section 104AB).
A local licence may be renewed under this section only if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: it has been renewed under section 104A, or
it is granted on or after the day on which this section comes into force.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Subsections (3) to (12), (13) and (14) of section 104A apply in relation to the renewal of a licence under this section as they apply in relation to the renewal of a licence under section 104A, subject to subsections (4) and (5).
Section 104A(3) (as applied) has effect as if the words “Subject to subsection (2)” were omitted.

In the case of an approved licence, if an applicant for renewal of the licence under this section makes a national nomination in accordance with section 104AB, section 104A (as applied) has effect as if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: subsections (4) and (13)(b) were omitted,
references to the nominated local digital sound programme service were references to the national digital sound programme service nominated under section 104AB, and
references to the nominated local radio multiplex service were references to the national radio multiplex service nominated under section 104AB.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section and sections 104AB and 104AC—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “approved licence” means a local licence approved by OFCOM for the purposes of this section;

“local digital sound programme service”, “local radio multiplex service”, “national digital sound programme service” and “national radio multiplex service” have the same meanings as in Part 2 of the Broadcasting Act 1996.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Before approving a licence for the purposes of this section, OFCOM must publish a document specifying—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the licence proposed to be approved, and
a period in which representations may be made to OFCOM.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Renewal under section 104AA: nomination of national services

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purposes of section 104AA, a “national nomination” by an applicant for the renewal of an approved licence is the nomination of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a national digital sound programme service provided or to be provided by the applicant, and
a national radio multiplex service.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A national nomination must be made in the application for the renewal of the approved licence or before OFCOM consider the application.

The applicant may not nominate a national digital sound programme service unless OFCOM are satisfied that, if the application in question were granted, the programmes included in that service in each calendar month would include at least 80% of the programmes included in the service provided under the approved licence.
A national nomination must specify the other approved licences (if any) in relation to which, in reliance on the nomination, an application may be made under section 104AC.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Variation of conditions relating to digital services

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a licence that is an approved licence has been renewed under section 104A and includes a local digital services condition,
an application has been made under section 104AA for the renewal of another approved licence and the applicant has made a national nomination under section 104AB, and
the nomination specifies the licence mentioned in paragraph (a) in accordance with section 104AB(4).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may, if the requirements of subsections (3) and (4) are met, vary the licence mentioned in subsection (1)(a) by—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: removing the local digital services condition, and
adding a national digital services condition.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must have received an application for the variation from the licence holder.

OFCOM must be satisfied that, if they varied the licence, the programmes included in the nominated national digital sound programme service in each calendar month would include at least 80% of the programmes included in the service provided under that licence.
In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “local digital services condition” means a condition requiring the licence holder to do all that the licence holder can to ensure that a local digital sound programme service is broadcast by means of a local radio multiplex service;

“national digital services condition” means a condition requiring the licence holder to do all that the licence holder can to ensure that the nominated national digital sound programme service is broadcast by means of the nominated national radio multiplex service until the day on which the licence (as renewed under section 104A) is to expire;
“nominated” means nominated in the nomination referred to in subsection (1)(b).”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 104A(14) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (as applied by section 104AA of that Act) does not prevent the determination of a date falling less than one year after the making of the determination where—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the Office of Communications consider that the relevant date for the purposes of that section (as applied) is a date which is not more than 15 months after the day on which this section comes into force, and
the determination is made as soon as practicable after that day.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The requirement under section 104AA(7) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 may be satisfied by the publication of a document before this section comes into force.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Variation of licence period following renewal

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 86(6) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (variation of licence period etc), after “section 97B” (inserted by section 30) insert “, 105A”.
Before section 106 (but after the heading preceding that section) insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Variation of licence period following renewal

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This section applies if the Secretary of State—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: has not nominated a date for digital switchover under section 97A for one or more relevant renewed services, or
has withdrawn the nomination of such a date and has not nominated another such date under that section.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may give notice to OFCOM fixing a date (the “termination date”) in relation to that service or such of those services as are specified or described in the notice.
The Secretary of State may fix different dates for different services but may not fix a date falling before 31 December 2015.

If the period for which a licence to provide a relevant renewed service is to continue in force ends after the termination date fixed for the service, OFCOM must by notice vary the licence so that the period ends on or before that date, subject to subsection (5).
OFCOM may not reduce the period so that it ends on a day falling less than 2 years after the date on which they issue the notice, unless the licence holder consents to such a reduction.

If the period for which a licence to provide a relevant renewed service is to continue in force ends on or before the termination date fixed for the service, OFCOM may not vary the licence so that the period ends after that date.

“Relevant renewed service” means a national service provided under a licence that has been renewed under section 103B or a local service provided under a licence that has been renewed under section 104AA.”
In section 199(5) of that Act (publication of notices by OFCOM), after “103,” insert “105A,”.
If on 31 December 2012, in relation to a relevant renewed service (as defined in section 105A(7) of the Broadcasting Act 1990)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: section 105A of that Act applies, but
the Secretary of State has not given a notice under that section,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: the Secretary of State must, before 31 December 2013, consider whether to give a notice under that section in relation to that service.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Content and character of local sound broadcasting services

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 106(1A) of the Broadcasting Act 1990 (conditions relating to departures from character of licensed service), after paragraph (d) insert “; or

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that, in the case of a local licence—

SubParagraph_PgfTag.SubPara_text: the departure would result from programmes included in the licensed service ceasing to be made at premises in the area or locality for which the service is provided, but
those programmes would continue to be made wholly or partly at premises within the approved area (as defined in section 314 of the Communications Act 2003 (local content and character of services)).”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 314 of the Communications Act 2003 (local content and character of local sound broadcasting services) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), in paragraph (a), omit the words from “but” to “that case”.
After that subsection insert—
Paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1) apply in the case of each local sound broadcasting service only if and to the extent (if any) that OFCOM consider it appropriate in that case.”
In subsection (7)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: before the definition of “local material” insert—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: ““approved area”, in relation to programmes included in a local sound broadcasting service, means an area approved by OFCOM for the purposes of this section that includes the area or locality for which the service is provided;”, and

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in the definition of “locally-made”, at the end insert “or, if there is an approved area for the programmes, that area”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After subsection (8) insert—
Before approving an area for the purposes of this section, OFCOM must publish a document specifying—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the area that they propose to approve, and
a period in which representations may be made to OFCOM about the proposals.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may withdraw their approval of all or part of an area at any time if the holder of the licence to provide the local sound broadcasting service concerned consents.
Where OFCOM approve an area or withdraw their approval of an area, they must publish, in such manner as they consider appropriate, a notice giving details of the area.”
The requirement under section 314(9) of the Communications Act 2003 may be satisfied by the publication of a document before this section comes into force.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Local radio multiplex services: frequency and licensed area

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: After section 54 of the Broadcasting Act 1996 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Variation of local radio multiplex licences: frequency or licensed area

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may, if the requirements of this section are met, vary a local radio multiplex licence by—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: varying the frequency on which the licensed service is required to be provided,
reducing the area or locality in which the licensed service is required to be available, or
extending that area or locality to include an adjoining area or locality.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM must have received an application for the variation from the licence holder.
The application must include a technical plan relating to the service proposed to be provided under the licence indicating, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the area or locality which would be within the coverage area of the service,
the timetable in accordance with which that coverage would be achieved, and
the technical means by which it would be achieved.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Before deciding whether to grant the application, OFCOM must publish a notice specifying—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the proposed variation of the licence, and
a period in which representations may be made to OFCOM about the proposal.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may vary the licence in accordance with the application only if they are satisfied that doing so would not unacceptably narrow the range of programmes available by way of local digital sound programme services to persons living in the area or locality for which, before the proposed variation, the local radio multiplex service is required to be available.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Renewal of radio multiplex licences

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 58 of the Broadcasting Act 1996 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Renewal of radio multiplex licences: supplementary

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by regulations—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: amend section 58, and
make further provision about the renewal of radio multiplex licences.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The regulations may, in particular, make provision about—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the circumstances in which OFCOM may renew a radio multiplex licence,
the period for which a licence may be renewed,
the information that OFCOM may require an applicant for renewal of a licence to provide,
the requirements that must be met by such an applicant,
the grounds on which OFCOM may refuse an application for renewal of a licence,
payments to be made in respect of a licence following its renewal, and
further conditions to be included in a licence following its renewal.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The regulations may, in particular, amend or modify this Part of this Act.
A statutory instrument containing the regulations may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

The power to make regulations under this section may not be exercised after 31 December 2015 (but this does not affect the continuation in force of any regulations made under this section before that date).”
In section 72(1) of that Act (interpretation of Part 2), before the definition of “radio multiplex service” insert—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: ““radio multiplex licence” means a licence to provide a radio multiplex service;”.

CrossHeading.CrossHeadingTitle: Regulation of television and radio services

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Application of regulatory regimes to broadcasters

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: In section 263 of the Communications Act 2003 (application of regulatory regimes to broadcasters), for subsection (4) substitute—

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by order provide for—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a condition included by virtue of this Act in a regulatory regime to be excluded from the regime;
a condition excluded from a regulatory regime by an order under this subsection to be included in the regime again.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An order under subsection (4) may, in particular, provide for a condition to be included or excluded for a period specified in the order.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Payment for licences

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 12 of the Wireless Telegraphy Act 2006 (charges for grant of licence) is amended as follows.
In subsection (5) at the end insert “, but this is subject to subsection (6).”
After subsection (5) insert—

Regulations under or for the purposes of subsection (1)(b), so far as it relates to payments during the term of a licence, may be made so as to apply in relation to a licence granted in accordance with regulations under section 14, but only in the following cases—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: where provision included in the licence with the consent of the holder of the licence provides for the regulations to apply;
where the licence includes terms restricting the exercise by OFCOM of their power to revoke the licence before the end of a period and that period has expired;
where the licence would, but for a variation, have ceased to have effect at the end of a period and that period has expired;
where the licence is a surrendered-spectrum licence.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Provision may not be made by virtue of subsection (6)(c) or (d) without the consent of the Secretary of State.
A wireless telegraphy licence is a “surrendered-spectrum licence” if —

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: it is granted under arrangements involving (before the grant or later) the variation, revocation or expiry of another wireless telegraphy licence;
the arrangements are with a view to enabling the holder of that other licence to comply with a limit applying to frequencies in respect of which a person may hold licences; and
it authorises the use after that variation, revocation or expiry of a frequency whose use until then was or is authorised by that other licence.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In relation to a surrendered-spectrum licence there may be more than one such other licence (“predecessor licence”) and a licence may be a predecessor licence to more than one surrendered-spectrum licence.”
Section 14 of the Wireless Telegraphy Act 2006 (bidding for licences) is amended as follows.
In subsection (5) after “those sums must” insert “, subject to subsection (5A),”.
After subsection (5) insert—
The regulations may, with the consent of the Secretary of State, make provision permitting or requiring a surrendered-spectrum licence to which the regulations apply to include—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: provision requiring all or part of a sum that would otherwise be payable to OFCOM under subsection (5) to be paid to a person who was or is the holder of a predecessor licence;
provision requiring a sum in addition to that payable to OFCOM under subsection (5) to be paid to such a person;
provision specifying any such sum or part or the method for determining it.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After subsection (8) insert—
In subsection (5A) “surrendered-spectrum licence” and “predecessor licence” have the meaning given by section 12(8) and (9).”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Enforcement of licence terms etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Chapter 4 of Part 2 of the Wireless Telegraphy Act 2006 (enforcement of Page 42regulation of radio spectrum) after section 43 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Special procedure for contraventions of certain provisions

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: OFCOM may impose a penalty on a person if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: that person is or has been in contravention in any respect of a provision, term or limitation of a wireless telegraphy licence;
OFCOM have notified that person that it appears to them that the provision, term or limitation has been contravened in that respect;
this section applies to that contravention by virtue of provision included in the licence; and
that contravention is not one in respect of which proceedings for an offence under this Chapter have been brought against that person.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A licence may provide in accordance with subsection (1)(c) that this section applies to the contravention of a provision, term or limitation only if it appears to OFCOM that a direction under section 5 requires the provision, term or limitation to be included in the licence.
Where OFCOM impose a penalty on a person under this section, they must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: notify that person of that decision and of their reasons for that decision; and
in that notification, fix a reasonable period after it is given as the period within which the penalty is to be paid.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A penalty imposed under this section—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: must be paid to OFCOM; and
if not paid within the period fixed by them, is to be recoverable by them accordingly.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: No proceedings for an offence under this Chapter may be commenced against a person in respect of a contravention in respect of which a penalty has been imposed by OFCOM under this section.
The amount of a penalty imposed under this section is to be such amount not exceeding 10 per cent of the relevant amount of gross revenue as OFCOM think—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: appropriate; and
proportionate to the contravention in respect of which it is imposed.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In section 44 of that Act (relevant amount of gross revenue), in subsections (1) and (10), after “43” insert “or 43A”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Classification of video games etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 2 of the Video Recordings Act 1984 (exempted video works) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: after “video work” insert “other than a video game”,
after paragraph (a) insert “or”, and
omit paragraph (c) (and the word “or” before it).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After that subsection insert—
Subject to subsection (2) or (3) below, a video game is for the purposes of this Act an exempted work if—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: it is, taken as a whole, designed to inform, educate or instruct;
it is, taken as a whole, concerned with sport, religion or music; or
it satisfies one or more of the conditions in section 2A.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 2 of that Act insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Conditions relating to video games

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The conditions referred to in section 2(1A)(c) are as follows.
The first condition is that the video game does not include any of the following—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: depictions of violence towards human or animal characters, whether or not the violence looks realistic and whether or not the violence results in obvious harm,
depictions of violence towards other characters where the violence looks realistic,
depictions of criminal activity that are likely, to any extent, to stimulate or encourage the commission of offences,
depictions of activities involving illegal drugs or the misuse of drugs,
words or images that are likely, to any extent, to stimulate or encourage the use of alcohol or tobacco,
words or images that are intended to convey a sexual message,
swearing, or
words or images that are intended or likely, to any extent, to cause offence, whether on the grounds of race, gender, disability, religion or belief or sexual orientation or otherwise.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (2) “human or animal character” means a character that is, or whose appearance is similar to that of—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: a human being, or
an animal that exists or has existed in real life,

TextContinuation.SubSection_PgfTag: but does not include a simple stick character or any equally basic representation of a human being or animal.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The second condition is that the designated authority, or a person nominated by the designated authority for the purposes of this section, has confirmed in writing that the video game is suitable for viewing by persons under the age of 12.
The Secretary of State may by regulations amend this section—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: by amending the first condition, or
by adding a further condition (or by amending or removing such a condition).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Regulations under this section may make provision by reference to documents produced by the designated authority.”
In section 3 of that Act (exempted supplies), after subsection (8) insert—

The supply of a video recording in the form of a machine of a type designed primarily for use in an amusement arcade is an exempted supply unless the video game (or, if more than one, any of the video games) that it contains—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: depicts, to any significant extent, anything falling within section 2(2)(a), (b), (c) or (d) or (3), or
is likely to any significant extent to stimulate or encourage anything falling within section 2(2)(a) or, in the case of anything falling within section 2(2)(b), is likely to any extent to do so.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The supply of any other video recording is an exempted supply if the recording is supplied for the purpose only of its use in connection with a supply that is an exempted supply under subsection (8A).”
At the end of that section insert—
The Secretary of State may by regulations amend this section and the regulations may, in particular—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: add a case in which the supply of a video recording is an exempted supply for the purposes of this Act, or
repeal a provision of this section.”

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Designated authority for video games etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After section 4 of the Video Recordings Act 1984 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Designated authorities for video games and other video works

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The power to designate a person by notice under section 4 includes power to designate different persons—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: as the authority responsible for making arrangements in respect of video games (“the video games authority”), and
as the authority responsible for making arrangements in respect of other video works (“the video works authority”).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where there are two designated authorities, references in this Act to the designated authority, in relation to a video work, are references to the designated authority responsible for making arrangements in respect of the video work, taking account of any allocation in force under section 4ZB.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Designated authorities: allocation of responsibility for video games

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Where there are two designated authorities, the video games authority may, with the consent of the video works authority, allocate to that authority responsibility—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: for a class of video games, or

for video games, or a class of video games, when (and only when) they are contained in a video recording that is described in the allocation (whether by reference to its contents, to the manner in which it is, or is to be, supplied or otherwise).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: If an allocation is in force—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the video works authority is responsible for making arrangements under this Act in respect of the allocated video games, and
the video games authority ceases to be responsible for making such arrangements.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: An allocation—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: must be made by a notice, and
may be withdrawn at any time by a notice given by the video games authority with the consent of the video works authority.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: When making or withdrawing an allocation under this section, the video games authority must have regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State.
A notice under this section must be—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: sent to the Secretary of State, and
published in such manner as the video games authority considers appropriate.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A question as to which designated authority is responsible for making arrangements in respect of a video game may be conclusively determined by the video games authority.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Designated authorities: video works included in video games

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The video games authority may make such arrangements in respect of video works included in video games as it considers are necessary for the purposes of fulfilling its responsibilities in respect of video games.

Where there are two designated authorities, the arrangements made by the video games authority under section 4 must, to the extent that the video games authority considers appropriate, include either or both of the following—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: arrangements for having regard to any classification certificate issued by the video works authority in respect of a video work included in a video game;
arrangements for obtaining and having regard to a determination by the video works authority as to the suitability of all or part of a video work included in a video game.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: For the purpose of determining the extent to which arrangements described in subsection (2)(a) or (b) are appropriate, the video games authority must—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: consult the video works authority, and
have regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In this section, “suitability” means suitability for the issue of a classification certificate or suitability for the issue of a classification certificate of a particular description.”
Schedule 1 (which contains further amendments of the Video Recordings Act 1984) has effect.

CrossHeading.CrossHeadingTitle: Copyright and performers’ property rights: licensing and penalties

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Extension and regulation of licensing of copyright and performers’ rights

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (the “1988 Act”) after section 116 insert—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Licensing of orphan works

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for authorising a licensing body or other person to do, or to grant licences to do, acts in relation to an orphan work which would otherwise require the consent of the copyright owner.
An authorisation or licence under the regulations in favour of any person must not preclude any authorisation or licence in favour of another person.
The regulations may provide for the treatment of royalties or other sums paid in respect of an authorisation or licence, including—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: the deduction of administrative costs;
the period for which sums must be held for the copyright owner;
the treatment of sums after that period (as bona vacantia or otherwise).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The regulations may provide for determining the rights and obligations of any person if a work ceases to be an orphan work.
The regulations may provide for the Secretary of State to determine whether any requirement of the regulations for a person’s becoming or remaining authorised has been met or ceased to be met.
In this Part references to a work as or as ceasing to be an orphan work are to be read in accordance with regulations made by the Secretary of State.
Regulations under subsection (6) may operate by reference to guidance published from time to time by any person.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Extended licensing schemes

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for authorising a licensing body to grant copyright licences (within the meaning of section 116) in respect of works in which copyright is not owned by the body or a person on whose behalf the body acts.
The regulations may not authorise the grant of a licence—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in respect of an unpublished work, or
in respect of rights excluded by notice given by the copyright owner in accordance with the regulations.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Subsections (2) to (5) of section 116A apply to regulations under this section (but subsections (3)(b) and (c) and (4) apply only in relation to an orphan work).

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: Regulation and enforcement

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: Schedule A1 confers powers to provide for—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: codes of practice relating to licensing bodies, and
the regulation of licensing bodies and of other persons authorised under section 116A or 116B.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ActClauseTitle_text: General

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Nothing in section 116B or Schedule A1 applies in relation to Crown copyright or Parliamentary copyright.
The powers conferred by sections 116A and 116B and Schedule A1 include in particular power—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: to make incidental, supplementary or consequential provision;
to make different provision for different purposes;
to make provision amending this Part;
to extend or restrict the jurisdiction of the Copyright Tribunal.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The power to make regulations under sections 116A and 116B and Schedule A1 is exercisable by statutory instrument.
A statutory instrument containing such regulations is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament, but that is subject to subsection (5).

Where the regulations amend this Part, a statutory instrument containing them may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before and approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament.”

Schedule 2 (which inserts Schedule A1 to the 1988 Act and makes provision in relation to performers’ property rights corresponding to provision made by this section in relation to copyright) has effect.
In the 1988 Act insert in the appropriate place—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in section 179 (index of defined expressions in Part 1)—
in section 212 (index of defined expressions in Part 2)—

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Increase of penalties relating to infringing articles or illicit recordings

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 is amended as follows.
In section 107 (criminal liability for making or dealing with infringing articles etc.) in subsections (4)(a) and (4A)(a) for “the statutory maximum” substitute “£50,000”.
In section 198 (criminal liability for making, dealing with or using illicit recordings) in subsections (5)(a) and (5A)(a) for “the statutory maximum” substitute “£50,000”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Public lending right

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: Section 5(2) of the Public Lending Right Act 1979 (interpretation) is amended as follows.
Before the definition of “local library authority” insert—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: ““author”, in relation to a work recorded as a sound recording, includes a producer or narrator;
“book” includes—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) a work recorded as a sound recording and consisting mainly of spoken words (an “audio-book”), and
(b) a work, other than an audio-book, recorded in electronic form and consisting mainly of (or of any combination of) written or spoken words or still pictures (an “e-book”);

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “lent out”—

DefinitionListItem.DefinitionList1_PgfTag: (a) means made available to a member of the public for use away from library premises for a limited time, but
(b) does not include communicated by means of electronic transmission to a place other than library premises,

TextContinuation.Definition_PgfTag: and “loan” and “borrowed” are to be read accordingly;

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “library premises” has the meaning given in section 8(7) of the Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964;”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: After the definition of “prescribed” insert—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: ““producer” has the meaning given in section 178 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988;”.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: At the end of the definition of “the register” omit “and”.
After the definition of “the Registrar” insert—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: ““sound recording” has the meaning given in section 5A(1) of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988.”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 is amended as follows.
In section 40A (permitted acts in relation to copyright works: lending of copies by libraries or archives), for subsection (1) substitute—
Copyright in a work of any description is not infringed by the following acts by a public library in relation to a book within the public lending right scheme—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: lending the book;
in relation to an audio-book or e-book, copying or issuing a copy of the book as an act incidental to lending it.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In subsection (1)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: “book”, “audio-book” and “e-book” have the meanings given in section 5 of the Public Lending Right Act 1979,
“the public lending right scheme” means the scheme in force under section 1 of that Act,
a book is within the public lending right scheme if it is a book within the meaning of the provisions of the scheme relating to eligibility, whether or not it is in fact eligible, and
“lending” is to be read in accordance with the definition of “lent out” in section 5 of that Act (and section 18A of this Act does not apply).”

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: In Schedule 2, in paragraph 6B (permitted acts in relation to performances: lending of copies by libraries or archives)—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: at the beginning insert—

SubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: The rights conferred by this Chapter are not infringed by the following acts by a public library in relation to a book within the public lending right scheme—

SubSubParagraph.sch_PgfTag.SubSubPara.sch_text: in relation to an audio-book or e-book, copying or issuing a copy of the book as an act incidental to lending it.

SubParagraphCont.sch_PgfTag.SubPara.sch_text: Expressions used in sub-paragraph (A1) have the same meaning as in section 40A(1).”;

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in sub-paragraph (2), for “this paragraph” substitute “sub-paragraph (1)”.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Power to make consequential provision etc

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may by regulations made by statutory instrument make incidental, supplementary, consequential, transitional, transitory or saving provision in connection with the amendments made by this Act.
The regulations may—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: make different provision for different purposes,
modify an Act passed before or in the same Session as this Act or subordinate legislation made before this Act is passed, and

where they are made in connection with an amendment made by section 27 or by a provision listed in section 48(3), modify a provision of an Act passed, or subordinate legislation made, before the day on which that amendment comes into force.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: A statutory instrument containing regulations under this section that amend or repeal a provision of an Act may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.
Any other statutory instrument containing regulations under this section is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
In this section—

Definition_PgfTag.Definition_text: “modify” includes amend, repeal or revoke;
“subordinate legislation” has the same meaning as in the Interpretation Act 1978.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Repeals

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: Schedule 3 (repeals) has effect.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Extent

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This Act extends to England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
An amendment of the following enactments that is made by this Act may be extended to any of the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man under the relevant extending power—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: Part 1 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988;
the Broadcasting Act 1990;
the Broadcasting Act 1996;
the Communications Act 2003;
the Wireless Telegraphy Act 2006.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: “Relevant extending power” means—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: in relation to amendments of Part 1 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988, section 157(2) of that Act;
in relation to amendments of the Broadcasting Act 1990, section 204(6) of that Act;
in relation to amendments of the Broadcasting Act 1996, section 150(4) of that Act;
in relation to amendments of the Communications Act 2003, section 411(6) of that Act;
in relation to amendments of the Wireless Telegraphy Act 2006, section 118(3) of that Act.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The power conferred by section 157(2)(c) of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (power to extend to British overseas territories) is exercisable in relation to any amendment made by this Act to Part 1 of that Act.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Commencement

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: This Act comes into force at the end of the period of two months beginning with the day on which it is passed, but this is subject to—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: section 27(8), and
subsections (2) and (3).

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The following come into force on the day on which this Act is passed—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: sections 6, 7, 8, 15 and 16(1),
sections 30 to 32, and
this section and sections 47 and 49.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The following come into force on such day as the Secretary of State may by order made by statutory instrument appoint—

Paragraph_PgfTag.Para_text: sections 18 to 20,

section 29 and the entries in Schedule 3 relating to sections 183A and 184 of the Broadcasting Act 1990 and Schedule 15 to the Communications Act 2003 (and section 46 so far as it relates to those entries),

sections 40(1) to (5) and 41(1), paragraphs 2 to 4, 6 to 9 and 10(2) of Schedule 1 (and section 41(2) so far as it relates to those provisions) and the entries in Schedule 3 relating to sections 2, 4 and 22 of the Video Recordings Act 1984 (and section 46 so far as it relates to those entries), and
section 44.

SubSection_PgfTag.SubSection_text: The Secretary of State may appoint different days for different purposes.

ClauseTitle_PgfTag.ClauseTitle_text: Short title

ClauseText.ClauseText_PgfTag: This Act may be cited as the Digital Economy Act 2010.
